Question: This term is used to describe an excessively rapid heartbeat

Which of the following is an electrical device that is placed to monitor for and correct cardiac arrhythmia by delivering a shock?
Which of the following is a non-invasive cardiac test?
Which of the following genetic principles is generally NOT applicable to cardiovascular genetic disorders?

Question: Mutations in SCN5A are associated with Long QT syndrome and Brugada syndrome. This is an example of
Which of the following disorders is characterized by the muscle that makes up the left ventricle stretching and becoming thinner, eventually spreading to the right ventricle and atria?
Which of the following cardiomyopathies is generally a genetic disorder, unlikely to be caused by other factors?
Which of the following is a potential limitation of multi-gene panels for cardiovascular genetic testing versus single gene testing?
CorrectAnswer: Increased number of variants of uncertain significance
Answer3: Deceased number of variants of uncertain significance

Question: Mutations in which gene make up the majority of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH)?
Which of the following is FALSE about coronary artery disease?
CorrectAnswer: Most often the result of a single gene mutation
Answer2: Risk factors include sedentary lifestyle, smoking, obesity, and high-fat diet
Answer3: Genetic testing is generally not part of routine care at this time

Question: Mutations in the LDL receptor gene are associated with which of the following?
Which of the following is TRUE about genetic testing for familial hypercholesterolemia (FH)?
CorrectAnswer: The benefit of genetic testing for HF is that screening can begin early for elevated cholesterol levels and risk factors can be modified before onset of disease
Answer1: There is no genetic testing clinically available because FH is a multifactorial disease.
Answer2: Genetic testing for FH has no clinical utility
Answer3: FH is an autosomal recessive disorder

Question: Dilated cardiomyopathy is most often displays which inheritance pattern?
Which of the following is FALSE with regard to familial hypercholesterolemia?
CorrectAnswer: Associated with no characteristic physical features
Answer1: Characterized by significant elevations in total serum cholesterol and LDL cholesterol early in life
Answer2: Increases the risk of coronary artery disease and myocardial infarction
Answer3: Homozygotes have earlier age of onset and more severe disease

Question: What is the approximate penetrance of pulmonary arterial hypertension with a BMPR2 mutation?
Which is FALSE regarding dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM)?
CorrectAnswer: Mutations in fewer than 10 genes have been found to be associated with DCM
Answer1: Mutations in TTN are the most common known genetic cause of DCM
Answer2: May be associated with conduction system disease
Answer3:
May be caused by mutations associated with sarcomeric proteins or proteins associated with the
contractile apparatus

Question: Which is FALSE with regard to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy?
Answer2: May present with shortness of breath (particularly with exertion), chest pain, palpitations, and syncope
Answer3: Can lead to sudden cardiac death

Question: Mutations in GLA result in
CorrectAnswer: Fabry disease, which can present with HCM
Answer1: Noonan syndrome, which can present with HCM
Answer2: Danon disease, which can present with HCM
Answer3: Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome, which can present with HCM

Question:
Generally what phenotype is most likely if an individual has more than one mutation that is associated with
hypertrophic cardiomyopathy?
CorrectAnswer: Earlier age of onset of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
Answer3: No difference from hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with one mutation

Question: Using the Schwartz criteria, a diagnosis of Long QT syndrome can be made based on
CorrectAnswer: EKG findings, clinical history, and family history
Answer3: Cardiac MRI, exercise stress test, and clinical history

Question: Mutations in which genes each make up about 40% of HCM?
Sudden unexpected nocturnal death syndrome (SUNDS) and _____________ are considered to be the same disorder.
Which of the following is generally NOT helpful in making a diagnosis of Brugada syndrome?
Mutations in which gene make up 15-30% of Brugada syndrome (the greatest proportion of Brugada syndrome compared to any other known gene)?
Which is NOT a characteristic trigger of arrhythmia in the most common types of Long QT syndrome?

Which of the following is FALSE with regard to Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome?
Answer1: Characterized by LQTS and sensorineural deafness
Answer3: Caused by mutations in KLQT1 (KCNQ1) and KCNE1

Question: Pulmonary arterial hypertension can occur along with which syndrome, particularly with mutations in ACVRL1.
Which disorder is characterized by cardiac electrical instability (QRS complexes with frequent and rapid changes in morphology) triggered by acute activation of the adrenergic nervous system?
Which of the following is TRUE about familial TTR amyloidosis?
CorrectAnswer: The V122I mutations is common in the African-American population
Answer1: Caused by mutations in the BMPR2 gene
Answer3: De novo mutations occur in less than 1% of cases

Question: Which of the following is TRUE about psychosocial issues in cardiovascular genetics?
CorrectAnswer:
Psychosocial issues in cardiovascular genetics may include issues surrounding uncertainty, changes in
perception of health, and guilt or blame
Answer1:
The psychosocial issues in cardiovascular genetics are very unique to these diseases and have no overlap
with other universal counseling issues
Answer2:
There are no psychosocial issues in cardiovascular genetics because the conditions can be managed with
medication and/or implantable cardioverter defibrillators
Answer3: The most significant psychosocial issue in cardiovascular genetics is denial

Question: Noonan syndrome is a condition that can be described as encompassing: short stature, lymphedema at birth, bleeding issues, delayed puberty, a short webbed neck, and a low hairline. What are the main heart features in this condition?
CorrectAnswer: Pulmonary valve stenosis and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
Explanation: Up to 20% of cases with have HCM and pulmonary valve stenosis is the most common congenital heart disease in Noonan’s.

Question: Mutations in LMNA cause a genetic condition that is seen in both boys and girls with contractures, muscle wasting, and arrhythmias and/or congestive heart failure. What condition is this?
What is the inheritance pattern of Barth Syndrome?
What is the most common inheritance pattern in genetic causes of dilated cardiomyopathies?
This metabolic condition can lead to cardiomyopathy, skeletal myopathy, and intellectual disability in males with mutations in the LAMP2 gene.
A woman was recently diagnosed with Loeys Dietz syndrome due to aortic root dilation, a bifid uvula, and scoliosis. What is the de novo rate for this condition?
Explanation: 25% of cases are inherited in an AD pattern. Most common mutations are TGFBR1, TGFBR2, and SMAD3

Question: Holt Oram is the most common hand-heart genetic conditions caused by mutations in TBX5. Your 25 year old patient want to know the chance of having a child with this condition. What do you tell her?
CorrectAnswer: It is dominant, a 50% chance with each pregnancy the child will be affected
Answer1: It is recessive, if her partner is also a carrier for the condition her children will have a 50% of being affected and a 50% chance of being a carrier
Answer2: It is x-linked, a 50% chance to have an affected male and 50% chance of having a carrier female
Answer3: It’s a somatic mutation, she could have up to a 50% chance of passing down the mutation

Question: Pulmonic valvular stenosis, cholestasis, and butterfly vertebrae are main clinical features of which condition?
Cardiomyopathy is a feature in this condition…
Explanation: mitochondrial diseases can affect the heart because it requires so much energy. 40% of patients with MELAS have cardiomyopathy, most are HCM.
